He disapproves as much as his Colleague at Paris, but does not venture so strongly to express his disapprobation— I spoke to him of the Negotiation between France and Buenos-Ayres recently divulged, and found him still more unprepared to talk of that, than of Spanish Affairs: it confirms him however in his opinion that the South-Americans are not competent to maintain Independent Governments— Dr Caldwell who is one of the Professors at the Transylvania University called twice at my house this day: once while I was at the Office, and again while we were at dinner. I missed seeing him.

22. IV:30. Bath in the Potowmack, with Charles; at the mouth of the Tyber Creek; a place which I frequented part of the summer of 1818. but not at all the last year— It is about one third of a mile further distant from my house than the spot near the bridge, and rather better for a bathing place— I rode in the Carriage to the Office. Captain Moses Rogers of the Steam-ship Savannah came to solicit an appointment under the Government, as commander of a floating Steam-battery. His ship Savannah was the first Steam-vessel that ever crossed the Ocean. He went last Summer to Liverpool, to Stockholm, and to Cronstadt— But the Emperor Alexander declined purchasing his ship, as the Government here have also done. The House at New-York with which he was associated have failed— The Steam-ship adventure has turned out a total loss— He is now to sell here the ship for the benefit of Creditors, and having a family to provide for he is very anxious to obtain this employment from the Government. He came to ask a Letter of recommendation from me to Mr Thompson the Secretary of the Navy, and also extracts of Letters from R. Rush, C. Hughes and G. W. Campbell recommending him to the
patronage of the Government. I asked Rogers to call again to-morrow— Captain O’Brien called again with his Papers. He has been in pursuit of Lewis Williams of North-Carolina, Chairman of the Committee of Claims, to obtain from him a declaration of the meaning of the Act of Congress for O’Brien’s relief, passed at the late Session of Congress. Williams who is a single man, lives with his father and when O’Brien reached the house he found that he had been some days gone into the State of Tennessee— So the old Commodore was obliged to bout Ship and make his return Voyage— He then wrote to Edwards of Connecticut a member of the Committee of Claims, to ask of him an explanation of the Law— Edwards answered him in substance that the Law must speak for itself— O’Brien gave me the Letter, and said it was a Connecticut Orange— There was no juice in it— He left his papers with me— The Instructions to the Marshals, with all the blank forms were this day printed in the National Intelligencer, my motive for which is to put them upon a more certain Record than that of the Department— This afternoon, a boy who had brought to the house a barrel of flour that had been purchased for family provisions, was bitten at the kitchen door, by a dog not belonging to me, but who followed the Coachman some time since to the house, and has remained here— The dog bit a small piece out of the boy’s leg. We had it washed with Cologne water, and dressed with lint and a rag, and sent the boy home.

23. V: Bath in the Potowmack, with Charles, at a new place behind the old Nottley-Young house— Captain Moses Rogers came again to the Office; I had forgotten to write the Letter which I had promised him to the Secretary of the Navy and therefore wrote it, while he was at the Office, and gave it to him— He is to call again to-morrow for the extracts. Mr Josiah Meigs called, on account of Mrs Forsyth— The current daily business of the Office has hitherto prevented me from finishing the Instructions to H. Middleton, and to J. M. Forbes; both of which have been commenced— Forbes has written one or two Letters from New-York, urging to have his immediately forwarded. I took them up yesterday; and this morning found it necessary to read over all the papers, relating to the claim upon the Government of Chili for property taken from American Citizens by Lord Cochrane— On this examination several striking coincidences raised in my mind a doubt, whether that interest in Chili ought to be entrusted to Prevost; and another, whether some notice of those things which look unfavourably to the character of Prevost ought not of be made known to himself, and enquired into. I therefore wrote to the President; enclosed to him all the Papers and asked his attention to those which bear especially upon Prevost, who with more ability than any other of the informal agents who have been employed in South-America, has not escaped the common error of making himself a blind partizan, not only to their struggle for Independence, but to their internal feuds—and in the case of these plundering outrages of Lord Cochrane, he has been to say the least very remiss in supporting the rights and interests of his Countrymen— Prevost is a special favourite of the President’s, and I am aware there is some delicacy and danger in presenting these facts to him in a manner which attaches blame to him— The censorial Power of the President of the United States, over the moral and official conduct of the Officers appointed and subject to removal by him, is one of those, the exercise of which is of the most extreme delicacy. There are cases when it is proper to mark disapprobation without expressing it— Others in which it must be unequivocally expressed, and among them such as require different degrees of severity—others finally which demand the permission to resign, or last of all, peremptory removal— In the discharge of this most painful and ungracious duty, the President seems to me, more governed by momentary feelings, and less by steady and inflexible principle than I think he ought— But his failing leans to Virtue’s side— He is universally indulgent, and scrupulously regardful of individual feelings— He is perhaps too reluctant to exercise this power at-all— He rather turns his eyes from misconduct, and betrays a sensation of pain when it is presented directly to him. Whether this weakness, as it appears to me to be, is not better than its proximate energy, is perhaps doubtful. In the theory of a President’s duties, with almost as much indulgence, and the same tenderness for the feelings of individuals, I should look for a little more vigilance to observe, and a little more rigour to controul the faults of Executive Officers— One of the consequences of this tendency to censorial laxity is the necessity under which I have often found myself, of presenting to the President cases requiring censure; and after having presented them of bringing them again and again before him, until something is done; for whatever he consents to do, unless it is to be executed immediately, he never thinks of it afterwards, and in the way of censure or punishment, if an order
that he gives should not be executed, I doubt whether he would ever notice it, unless by having it again called to his attention— The heat of the weather begins seriously to affect my ability to labour; and this evening, after dinner, I made two or three attempts to write and was obliged to give them up.

24. IV:30. Bath in the Potowmack with Charles, at the same place as yesterday. A person by the name of Asael Bailey came to my house with another man, to obtain a patent for a floating machine for net fishery. He had applied some time since for a Patent which Dr. Thornton declined giving him, on the ground that he himself had invented the same thing; of which, a Mr Delancey of New-York, who had also claimed a patent for the same invention had given up his pretensions and had not taken out the patent— I told Bailey to apply again at the Patent Office, and ask Dr. Thornton to send me Bailey’s Petition, Specification and Model, and also the specification and drawing deposited by Delancy. They were accordingly brought by Mr Elliot, to my Office, and upon examination of them there appeared to me, to be a sufficient difference of principle between them to warrant the issuing of Patents in both cases; subject to a decision by Law whether one of them should be vacated for interference with the other. I directed therefore that the Patent to Bailey should be issued. The Doctor did not send his own Specification or model, and I suppose has never made them. He has such an inventive genius, that scarcely any person applying for a patent ever escapes his anticipations; and at one time it became necessary to put his ingenuity under interdict, and require him to disclose once for all, his pretensions. Mr Bennett of Alexandria, candidate for the appointment of Consul at Pernambuco came with two recommendatory Letters, and said that he could produce others. I told him I had already written to the President proposing his name for the appointment, and advised him to call again in three or four days, within which I expected to receive the President’s Answer— Arthur Middleton came to inform me that he proposed to leave the City, the second of next Month for New-York, to embark there on the 10th.I told him I would have a packet ready for his father by the beginning of the Month; and would transmit others to him at New-York— Captain O’Brien also came, concerning his Accounts— Fahrenheit’s thermometer was at 94, and the heat so intense that I found it almost impossible to write. I rode to and from my Office. On returning home to dinner, I found Robert Buchanan at the house. His mother Mrs Frye, had a son last Night— Mrs. Adams and the Children went this Evening to see her.

25. III:45. The Night was the hottest we have yet had for the Season, and as usual in such weather I had very little sleep. I rose with the dawn of day, and commenced a Memorandum for the compilation of a Manual for the distribution of the business in the Department of State— I began with a minute of the principal branches of business, as they occurred to my recollection, without order or arrangement. May this undertaking not share the fate of so many others which I have commenced and abandoned in the course of my life. Bath with Charles in the Potowmack, and returned to the place which I have most frequented, just above the Bridge— We all attended Church at Mr. M’Cormick’s. He read Prayers for the fourth Sunday after Trinity, and preached from Ecclesiastes XI: 9. “Rejoice, O young man, in thy youth; and let thy heart cheer thee in the days of thy youth, and walk in the ways of thy heart, and in the sight of thine eyes: but know thou, that for all these things, God will bring thee into judgment.” It was a plain and sensible discourse of admonition to youth. This Book of Ecclesiastes appears to be Supplementary to that of Proverbs. It contains some of the most exquisitely beautiful passages of the whole Bible. It is a moral dissertation, which commences with the assertion of the general Vanity of all human existence, and concludes with the exhortation to Fear God and keep his commandments; asserting this to be the whole duty of man—and reminding the reader that God shall bring every work into judgment, with every secret thing, whether it be good, or whether it be evil. This the great foundation of the Hebrew system of Morals, which was thus grappled in union indissoluble with religion— It recurs in the Sentiment of the text, which is not intended to debar youth from the enjoyments in which it delights, but on the contrary contains not only permission but injunctions to partake of them freely, coupled only with the caution to enjoy within the bounds allowed by the Commandments of God— There is no
more perfect morality than this— The general complexion of thought in the book is melancholy— It bears internal evidence of a man who had himself enjoyed too much; who had been satiated with good things; and miserable from the gratification of all his desires— There never existed indeed a man in whom the vanity of human life was so strongly exemplified as in Solomon— He was a king with absolute power, and had a reign of uninterrupted Peace and Prosperity till the last Stage of his life— He was the wisest and most pious of men— A prophet, divinely inspired—with an inextinguishable thirst of knowledge; and an exquisite relish for literature and Science— With such Powers, and such dispositions, he became the victim of sensuality and of superstition; he died in the arms of idolatresses, and left rebellion and dismemberment as the inheritance of his Son. He wrote this book in the decline of life; under the bitter disappointment of supreme felicity; yet full of the wisdom both of inspiration and of experience; and overflowing with the richest oriental poetic imagery. It is a peculiarity in the writings of Solomon, that they appear to be addressed to an individual; and from that practice he frequently resorts to the figure of apostrophe, when he means only to express a general maxim— In this text the young man whom he accosts is every young person who reads the book, and this interjective mode of writing adds great force, and animation to the precept— The monitions “walk in the ways of thine heart and in the sight of thine eyes,[”] are all figurative to signify the indulgence of inclination and of passion; the ways of the heart are the propensities of animal nature— The sight of the eye, is the pursuit of sensual pleasure to which the principal attractions are by the eyes— In the German Bible of Luther, this verse begins the twelfth and last Chapter, as it seems to me evident that it ought— It is the commencement of the exhortation to youth which is continued into that chapter, and in which there is that incomparable allegorical description of old age and death— The heat of the weather was this day so great that I had not that command of attention to the preacher which his subject deserved— After returning home, I was unable to write, and had no other occupation than the perusal of the Newspapers— Towards evening there came up a light Thunder-shower, by which the atmosphere was much cooled and refreshed.

26. IV:30. A cool and pleasant day; but in attempting to write, I found in the language of the Preacher, brought yesterday to my attention; that “the keepers of the house trembled, more than ever[”]— It was with the utmost difficulty that I could write at-all. I find nothing so trying to my Constitution as the excessive heats of this climate. I bathed with Charles in the river, and found this morning on the right side of the Bridge a place better than any that I have yet used. Mr Hickey came here this morning with a subscription book for Building a second Roman Catholic Church in this City. I went late to my Office, because the Morning bath taking nearly two hours of time, I am obliged to allow them after breakfast for the Diary— I was without interruption from visitors at the Office, with the exception of a Mr Howell of Rhode-Island; a son of the District Judge there, and a Candidate for employment as a Clerk in any of the public Offices. He was introduced to me by Mr Bailey, who told me that Mr Morton left the City to return home this Morning. I was employed in drafting Instructions for Mr Middleton, and upon the special object of his Mission; the question between the United States and Great-Britain, upon the Construction of the first Article of the Treaty of Ghent; concerning Slaves and other private property: as usual for the preparation of almost all instructions, there was a considerable number of papers, which I was obliged to look up, and peruse; so that I wrote very little of the draft— It is a singular, and I apprehend will prove a very difficult and delicate negotiation— During the late War, the British Naval Officers stationed in our waters, and who landed on our shores, received all the runaway Slaves who could escape to them, and issued proclamations inviting them to join them. They enlisted numbers of them among their troops, and formed one or two regiments of them— They also took numbers of them prisoners in their predatory excursions into the Country. At the conclusion of the Treaty of Peace, the British Plenipotentiaries agreed to the Article stipulating for the restoration of all places taken, without carrying away any of the artillery or other property originally taken in them and remaining in them at the time of the exchange of ratifications, or any slaves or other private property. Notwithstanding this they actually carried away many hundred Slaves; and great numbers of them within the whole description applied by the Article to public property—namely Slaves who had not been removed from the places where they were originally taken. When Sir Alexander Cochrane, and Admiral Cockburn were called upon after the Peace to carry this Article into effect, they found it obliged them to restore to their Masters, Slaves whom they had enticed away from them by promises
of Freedom. They therefore set forth a violent and unnatural Construction of the Article to avoid compliance with it, refused to restore the Slaves, and with a very few exceptions carried them all away— Their pretence was that the clause, limiting the promise not to carry away public property, to such as should have been in the places taken when captured, and remain there at the ratification of the Treaty, must be extended also to Slaves and other private property— They changed altogether the terms of the Article, to give it this Construction, and the British Government have persisted in it— After a thorough discussion of the subject; first between the Commissioners who were sent by the American Government to receive the Slaves, and the British Officers who refused to restore them; next between Mr Monroe when Secretary of State, and Anthony St. John Baker, the British Chargé d’Affaires, and finally between me and the Lords Liverpool, Bathurst and Castlereagh in England, each party adhering to its own Construction of the Article, a proposal was made on our part that the question should be submitted to the decision of some friendly Sovereign or State— To this the British Government after a delay of two years assented, and it was stipulated by the fifth Article of the Convention of 20. October 1818— It has since been agreed that the Emperor of Russia should be the Umpire— This reference of a question upon the construction of an Article of a Treaty to a third party is unusual, but not unexampled; though there is something whimsical in the idea that the United-States and Great-Britain, both speaking English, should go to the Slavonian Czar of Muscovy, to find out their own meaning in a sentence written by themselves in the language common to them both— The question is one however, not of language, but of Grammar, or rather there is no question at-all: in strictness of grammar the sentence admits of no other construction than that for which we contend— In the looseness of common discourse the whole sentence might be carelessly spoken, with the meaning for which the British insist, but not without a solecism— The plain truth as I believe it is that the British Plenipotentiaries at Ghent, and their Government agreed to it without reflecting upon what they promised by it— The stipulation was perfectly just and proper, and their difficulty about carrying it into execution arose from the preceding wrong of their own Officers in enticing away the Slaves by promises of Freedom. This reference of the question, is a sort of drawing lots for the event— It gives us one more chance for Justice— I made an attempt this Evening to proceed in the projected sketch of a manual for the Department; but without success. I found writing too irksome— This day was the full Harvest Moon.

27. V: The morning was so cool, that Charles shewed a disinclination to taking the bath, and it was accordingly omitted. It was nevertheless near Noon when I went to the Office; and I made very little progress upon the Instructions to Mr Middleton. It occurred to me that a special memoir upon the Slave question might be necessary or at least useful, and while I was meditating upon it, the morning passed away— Captain O’Brien besieged me again about his accounts, and after a long discussion with him, I told him he must make out a regular account of all his charges against the Government, and present it to the fifth Auditor Pleasonton— He would state his objections to the admission of any of the items in it, which he could not pass, and I would then decide upon them— Mr B. L. Lear came and offered me a few Shares of the Metropolis Bank Stock, which I agreed to take— Mrs. Adams spent this Evening with the Children, at her Sister Frye’s— I found when I came home a Letter from James L. Edwards, about the lease of the house in which he lives—containing objections to the draft that I had sent him.

28. V: After a race of five Months, I have once more redeemed the arrears of this Diary, and am writing, the morning of the day here noted— I bathed with Charles before breakfast in the Potowmack; at the place last discovered; which is preferable to any of the others. Hickey called here for an Answer to James L. Edwards’s Letter— I desired him to tell Edwards that I thought he had not dealt fairly with me, in withholding his objections to my draft of the lease, until after the purchase of the house was concluded— That now, if he could make any arrangement to replace me in the situation I was in before the bargain was concluded I should prefer it to every thing else— And if he could not, I wished him to send me a draft of such a lease as he was willing to sign; and I would
accept or decline it. Rode to the Office. Arthur Middleton came for a paper which I had promised him being a copy of the ordinance of the Emperor of Russia concerning the privileges of foreign Ministers at his Court, for the admission of articles free from duties. This paper had been transmitted to the Department by William Pinkney when he was at St. Petersburg. Last week I had promised a copy of it to Middleton who wanted it for his father, and desired Mr Brent the chief Clerk to look it up— The next day when Middleton came for it, Brent told me that it could not be found— Certain as I was of the existence of the paper, I requested that a more earnest search should be made for it; but when Middleton came this Morning, it was still not to be found. I was then obliged to overhaul the whole of Pinkney’s Correspondence myself and after a search of an hour or more found the paper. This happens to me almost every week, and is among the strongest trials of my Patience— It results from the want of a regular method of keeping the Papers; or in other words from a defective organization of the Department. I was yet engaged the remnant of the Office hours in preparing the Instructions for Mr Middleton, and particularly in reviewing our controversy with Great-Britain upon the Construction of the first Article of the Treaty of Ghent— I found upon re-examination of the British arguments that they had not been all replied to— Some of them are so weak and sophistical that one feels ashamed to answer them; others are plausible and insidious; and there is a tone of dogmatism in these, as in most others of the State Papers of the British Cabinet, which seems to say, if you will take this for reason, well and good—if not you must put up with it as you can—and take it for our will. Stat pro ratione voluntas. As I proceed with the draft of the Instructions I find much to say, and views of the question of a delicate nature, but which I believe must be presented to the Emperor— The Article as it stands is not susceptible of a question, and the British cannot make one, without a perversion of the plainest rules of Grammar— The real state of the case was that the British agreed to the Article, without considering what it bound them to— They had carried on a dishonourable war by stealing, and debauching Slaves, under promises of Freedom— They signed the Article promising to carry away no Slaves, without adverting to its operation upon their previous promises to the Slaves, and when summoned to perform their engagement they endeavoured to escape from it by prevarication— Now all this must be made manifest to the Emperor Alexander, and the unprincipled character of the war as carried on by the British must be thoroughly disclosed. How and at what time to do this will be a consideration requiring great discretion and dexterity—but the Instructions to Mr Middleton ought to lay open the subject to the bottom. I wrote till five, and suppose I have yet at least three days more of work upon this draft before it can be finished— We had visitors this evening, Messrs. Poletica, Stackelberg and Roth; also Mr Bailey, of the Department of State, and Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith. Bailey gave me notice of his wish to visit his friends in Massachusetts.

29. IV:30. Bath with Charles, who was out two hours before shooting. At the Office there came Mr Bennett, a Candidate for the appointment of Consul at Pernambuco. I had sent his former application and the recommendations of him to the President, and received for answer that another application had been made to him for a Mr Bibby, to which he had given some encouragement; so that the appointment must for the present be suspended. I advised Bennett to obtain further Recommendations, and promised to forward them to the President— Fahrenheits Thermometer was again this day at 92 and I was obliged to ride to and from the Office— There I was yet engaged upon the draft for Mr Middleton’s Instructions, which I did not finish— My solicitude upon this subject is perhaps too great. In the paper that I am preparing there is much repetition of what has been said before; and much which it will be very difficult for Middleton to say at-all. If the Emperor undertakes to decide the question at all, himself, what he will require will be a very concise and summary Statement of the question, presented in a striking point of view— For there is nothing that Emperors and Kings loathe so much as long arguments. On the other hand all those who have interests of property in litigation insist upon having every thing said for them that can be said, and if any thing alledged by the adversary is left without answer, they are prone to attribute any failure of their cause to the omission. My object is to put Middleton in possession of the whole subject, and to prepare him with answers to every thing that has been said on the British side: but he must use it all in his discretion; and must abridge the argument in presenting it to the Emperor as much as possible, without balking the merits of the Question.
Mr Mariano called at my house this Evening. Mrs Adams spent it at her Sister Smith’s where I also went for an hour— Dr and Mrs Thornton, and her mother, Mrs. Brodeau were there.

30. IV:45. Bath alone; Charles having heated himself in a shooting chace, and declined going with me— It was seven O’Clock when I left home and I found the tide not more than half-risen— At the Office there came a Mr Le Gris a Frenchman, from New-Orleans, not a Citizen of the United States, but having resided within them more than two years and therefore entitled to take out Patents. He had obtained a certificate from the Patent-Office, that he had deposited claims there to several inventions for which Patents would be issued on payment of 30. dollars for each of them into the Treasury—but he said they had given him this certificate only for about thirty inventions, and he had upwards of a hundred and fifty more, for which he wished to obtain the same document but it was refused him— He had not money to pay for these Patents at present, but he wished to secure the right to them, and then to advertise them, by which he hoped to raise the money necessary to pay the Treasury fees— I asked him if all these inventions were his own?—every one—was he prepared to affirm this upon Oath?—yes— Then he had only to deposit at the Patent Office a specification of each invention, and they would give him there a certificate for the 150 like that which they had given him for the thirty. He went off apparently quite satisfied— As I was short of time for the preparation of H. Middleton’s Instructions, I could not indulge my curiosity by enquiries what the inventions of this Genius were who breeds new discoveries, by multitudes like the spawning of fish. I was much engaged upon Middleton’s Instructions, without being able to finish them— The day was intensely hot. Fahrenheit at 94. and I rode to and from the Office— The Sun blazed the whole day from a cloudless sky, and when evening came it was with a breathless calm, scarcely more supportable than the fervour of noon day. I could not write in the Evening.

Day. Resembles in its general character that of the last Month— The range of my rising hour has been from III:45 to VI:30— The average IV:53. Having very steadily begun the day by writing in this Journal, I have redeemed its arrears, and am now keeping with the current of the time— The Emperor Titus after passing a day in which he recollected no good deed, said he had lost a day— Enquiring upon self-examination how many days of my life have passed which I could with a clear Conscience say I had not lost, another question occurs of what may properly be termed doing good. In the instance of the Emperor Titus, I suppose it meant acts of beneficence to individuals; the objects and the means for which could not fail to recur every day to a Roman Emperor. To a person in private life, the object must occasionally and the means often fail— In my station it is a constant source of mortification that the disproportion of the means is so great to that of the objects— But good offices, and kindness to individuals are but a single branch of the duties of doing good. In the relations of domestic life, and in those of neighbourhood there are continual occasions for doing good or evil— In public life it is doing good to serve one’s Country— And Genius has always the means of doing good to all mankind. I have always considered it my duty to do good to the utmost of my power; but in the selection and employment of the means of doing it, I have not been successful according to my wishes. It must be inspiration from above.
